awd_titl_txt: Optimization and Application of Next Generation Steels in Construction
awd_abstract_narration:
This research aims to advance knowledge leading to buildings with sustainability and structural resilience, while maintaining economic efficiency and the competitiveness of domestic steel production, by advancing the application of next-generation steels into building construction. A large class of new, high-performance steels has been developed for automotive applications to great success, but various technical challenges must be overcome before these steels can be widely integrated into building construction. A potential application is cold-formed steel studs and joists in buildings that employ sheet steels with thicknesses similar to next generation automotive steels.  The possible benefits of using these next-generation steels include more efficient material use and construction, and lower initial and life-cycle costs. These steels also offer the potential for structural engineers and architects to create novel solutions in design and construction.    
 
The objective of this research is to overcome the barriers in the application of next generation steels to cold-formed steel building construction and begin the optimization of the uses of these steels in this building system. Optimization and application of the use of next generation steels in cold-formed steel framing requires overcoming scientific barriers: generalized strength prediction of these uniquely strong but slender members is needed for engineering design, a deeper understanding of the material ductility that structural applications require is needed so that the new steels can be tailored to their demands at minimum cost, optimized shapes specific to construction applications are needed for efficiency, and prototyped solutions are needed to provide experimental evidence of superior performance. A series of targeted experiments at the material, connection, and member scale will be studied along with computational nonlinear collapse simulations and shape optimization to address the barriers to the adoption of next generation steel in construction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Buildings are fundamental to our society, and societal needs for buildings: more housing, costing less, and providing resilience and greater sustainability require innovation. This project provided a means for engineers designing buildings from steel to begin to utilize the revolution in steel materials that was borne out of innovation for the automobile industry over the last 20 years. Automotive advanced high strength sheet steels, commonly less than 2mm thick, have 2-4 times the capacity of conventional mild steel and are today used in selected portions of cars to decrease weight (thereby decreasing emissions) and increase safety. This project provided the necessary fundamental research to begin the process of utilizing these new sheet steels in building construction; in particular, cold-formed steel framing utilizes the same thickness of steel to provide the primary members of a building and is the ideal candidate for translation.  

Numerous impediments exist to adopting new materials in buildings, but chief among them is cost and the need for engineers to reliably design with the new material utilizing consensus approved design specifications adopted into building codes. Working with industry the project team identified two advanced high strength steels: dual-phase and martensitic, that had the potential to be the lowest cost given the strength benefit. The team investigated these materials and structural members and connections formed from these materials in detail in the research. To develop engineering guidance the team had to address fundamental performance issues that had not been solved in automotive applications. Translation of advanced high strength steels to building construction requires a deeper understanding of connections that are specific to buildings, such as bolted and screwed components (welding and adhesives are common in automotive applications). In addition, structural members are longer, open, and commonly more slender than similar components in automotive applications – thus fundamental strength in compression and bending must be fully understood. The extent to which existing methods used by building structural engineers are applicable to these much higher strength steels is an open question, and one the research examined in detail.

Through detailed testing and computational simulations, the project team addressed these fundamental issues for advanced high strength sheet steel’s application to cold-formed steel framing. Our connection testing demonstrated that current methods available to engineers for strength prediction are generally applicable, though specific reductions are needed for steels that have limited ductility. One further, the team demonstrated that newer methods for understanding ductility of these sheet steels can provide more reliable means for engineers to predict their strength. Specific recommendations for engineers designing with these materials in connections were developed.

Our member testing demonstrated that higher strength steels can lead to changes in expected member response. While the increased strength is always beneficial, in some cases under load the members formed from higher strength steels do not receive the full benefit one might expect due to the introduction of new buckling behavior and interactions. This inefficiency can be mitigated by optimizing the shape of the member and by providing supplemental bracing. Our research demonstrated both of these solutions in experiments and simulations. All of this work is now being condensed into provided recommendations to the national committees that create engineering standards for cold-formed steel buildings. While more work needs to be done to completely enable these innovations this project provides a sound basis for structural engineers to utilize these new steels and provide more efficient, sustainable, and resilient buildings to society.

 


Last Modified: 01/02/2023
Modified by: Benjamin W Schafer

Images (1 of )
  • Cold-formed steel is used extensively in building construction, but the type of steel used has seen little change, this project looks at the adoption of Advanced High Strength Steels (AHSS) for use in light steel framing and building construction.
    Chu Ding and Ben Schafer
    Benjamin W Schafer
    Overview of CFS in Construction
  • Summary of lap-shear connection tests performed as part of the project
    Own work.
    Copyrighted
    Benjamin W Schafer
    AHSS bolted lap-shear connection tests
  • Isolated and interacted buckling modes are observed in flexural testing of members fabricated from AHSS sheet - local-distortional interaction is not covered in the current codes in the U.S.
    Own work.
    Copyrighted
    Benjamin W Schafer
    Buckling modes observed in flexural testing
  • Summary of compression testing program on members fabricated from AHSS sheet steels
    Own work.
    Copyrighted
    Benjamin W Schafer
    Summary of compression testing program
  • Sigma sections improve the strength of the members at all lengths and for all sheet steels, but the failure mechanism and load drop can be more drastic, as shown here.
    Own work.
    Copyrighted
    Benjamin W Schafer
    Compression testing results for C vs. Sigma cross-sections
  • Steels with lower elongation require correction when using the current code for connection strength, existing reductions work reasonably well.
    Own work.
    Copyrighted
    Benjamin W Schafer
    Correlation between ductility and strength vs. current code provisions for connection tests
